project.description: My friend is getting married!  I'm designing an interactive card for them as part of my present.  The idea is that there will be some LEDs arranged in a heart that will light up when you press a button.
project.title: Electronic Wedding Card

steps.description: My friend is getting married!  I'm designing an interactive card for them as part of my present.  The idea is that there will be some LEDs arranged in a heart that will light up when you press a button.
steps.name: Project Overview

steps.description: The general idea is to have a laser cut card with a blinking LED heart.  I'd like to do 3 concentric hearts that light up in a sequence, so I started off by designing the card on paper and then moving to Illustrator to design the circuit.
steps.name: Sketching out the card

steps.description: Oops, actually, I just have one day to build this thing, so I'm just going to do one heart that flashes. ( :
steps.name: Switching to one heart

steps.description:
I love using Illustrator, so I used it to design my card.  I put all the different parts of the card in different layers to help myself organize the different components.  

One tricky thing was figuring out how to make laser-cutterable letters.  The issue is that when you laser cut letters, any letters with enclosed forms (like o's, a's, etc.) will look funny because the centers will be cut out (unless you use stencil fonts, most of which I find to be really ugly).  To get around this, I followed this excellent tutorial for adding material around letter openings:

http://www.instructables.com/id/Laser-Cut-Stencil-Letters/
steps.name: Designing the card

steps.description:
I started off by doing a bunch of test cuts to make sure that I could score the card (at the bend); I found that last time I made a card, it was hard to fold by hand since the card stock is thick.  

BUT I found that the laser cutter cut all the way through despite my test cuts!  I think it's because the laser cutter was on a raster setting and did multiple passes.  So instead, I just did a very light vector cut.
steps.name: Laser Cutting the Card

steps.description: I found some images on Google and put them together to form the graphic on the inside of the card.  I then traced over the image using some vellum and markers; it turned out better than I thought it would be!
steps.name: Designing the Interior

steps.description: After designing the circuit in Illustrator (and printing out the image to double-check the dimensions), I cut the circuit on the vinyl cutter.  One thing that I learned from last time I made a card is that it's worth cutting out the outline for the card on the vinyl cutter itself.  That makes it much easier to align the circuit on the card.
steps.name: Vinyl cutting the card

steps.description: Whoops, it turns out that somehow things got scaled in my Illustrator file, and the footprint for the different electronic components were too big.  Always good to double check with a print out!  Now that it's properly designed, I'm cutting out the circuit again.  Good thing the vinyl cutter is pretty quick!
steps.name: Vinyl cutting the circuit...again

steps.description:
I programmed an ATTiny45 using the programmer I made last time:

http://buildinprogress.herokuapp.com/projects/8/steps/4

My program is just the basic Arduino blink example so that all the lights in the heart blink repeatedly.
steps.name: Programming the Arduino

steps.description: Weeding the circuit took some time, but in the end, it turned out pretty clean.  I'm happy with it!
steps.name: Putting together the circuit

steps.description:
I really didn't like how my battery holder looked last time (I used a binder clip to hold the battery in place), so I went ahead and designed a new holder for the battery.  I wrapped the circuit around the back of the card and used neodymium magnets to hold the battery in place.  It worked surprisngly well!  To hide the messiness, I made a little door cover for the battery.  

I've gotta tell Jie about this...
steps.name: Designing a battery holder

steps.description: My switch ended up being a little bit of a last minute addition, so unfortunately, I had to manually cut a hole by hand through the different layers of the card.  For the switch, I backed a piece of paper with copper tape that would help close the circuit.
steps.name: Adding the switch

steps.description:
And then it all came together...

My assembly order (from back to front) was as follows:

  1. vinyl cut circuit layer
  2. mask layer (with holes for the LED)
  3. vellum layer (with graphic)
  4. frame (to hide the messiness on the edges)

I miraculously finished before 10 PM!  Hurrah!
steps.name: Assembling Everything

steps.description:
Yay, the card is done!  I'm really happy with how it turned out.  I feel like I've learned a lot since doing my first card.  Here are some helpful tips for putting together your own card:

  • make sure you print out your circuit to scale before you cut it on the vinyl cutter.  This will save you the hassle of realizing things aren't in the right place!
  • when creating your circuit on the vinyl cutter, cut out the entire outline that you hope to place the circuit on (this makes it easy to align)
  • magnets work really well for holding batteries into place (and are much easier to hide than binder clips!)
  • any mask that you make (to hide the circuitry) should span the entire width and height of the card interior – this makes the card look much cleaner!
steps.name: It's done!
